ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed speaking and writing skills.
Different tenses and more advanced grammars and vocabulary. Improved speaking, reading, listening and writing.
More advanced speaking, listening and vocabulary. Exactly what you'd expect from an L4
Learned Korean language skills!
I learned a lot of Korean grammar, vocabulary, and culture.
I continued my basic knowledge of Korean and learned more advance grammatical structures/vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are that the course was organized well and Professor Lim created a great space for learning. No weaknesses.
Strength: very hands-on learning, easy to follow instructor and support there when needed

It was a great continuation of L3, and it was always a class I looked forward to going to every day. I think the class would improve if there were more assignments outside of class. The few that we had were actually very fun and very memorable, so I think it's a great way to learn the language.

I love the Korean department at Yale so much. Every class I've taken has been one of my favorites and choosing to do this as my language was one of the best decisions I've made here. The courses are so collaborative and so fun. I look forward to going every day. 

I wish this class had been taught more in Korean as it was supposed to be, as this would have helped develop our listening skills and confidence in speaking. I also wish there would have been more reinforcement of previous concepts in new lessons, because I found that I would often very quickly forget old grammar or vocabulary once we moved past it as it was just never touched on again. This is also my fault for not doing more reinforcement outside of class on my own but doing more in class would have been very helpful.
I truly enjoyed this course and felt surrounded by other students who wanted to learn Korean

Strengths:   is one of the most supportive professors Ive had at Yale. Really great at answering questions.

Weaknesses: I wish there was more daily homework/opportunities for practice. I feel like my Korean wouldve improved if I were given daily assignments.

This course is quite well-organized and ensures that everyone in the classroom is able to take part. Our speaking, listening, writing, and reading skills were always challenged with students constantly being put on the spot to participate. This class can be a little fast-paced, but its nothing that students won't get adjusted to and I would argue it makes for a better learning process.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, for anyone looking for a language credit, I'd highly recommend taking Korean. The Korean department at Yale is amazing.
Yes, definitely! Loved my prof and he made class very enjoyable!
Absolutely! Just know that you get what you put into it. If you really want to see big improvement, you will need to study every day on your time.

Absolutely. The Korean department at Yale is amazing, and I have loved every single class I've taken with them from L1 to L4. I love going to this class every day and have met some of my best friends here in Korean. The workload is not very high and the grading is very kind but still requires you to work hard and learn. I hope I get to take more Korean classes in the future. If you are looking to take a new language, this is one you won't regret.
Highly!
Yes! Korean is fun to learn and definitely try to get  !
Yes, definitely.
If they are continuing the Korean sequence, yes, yes I would. It is a great course taught by an equally great instructor.
